<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 6: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://www.eecs.mit.edu/"><i>Course 6 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course6.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=6&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+++6&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>6.00-6.299</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m6b.html">6.30-6.799</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m6c.html">6.80-6.ZZZ</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>Basic Undergraduate Subjects</h2>
<a name="6.00"></a>
<p><h3>6.00 Introduction to Computer Science and Programming
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-7-2
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-100</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to computer science and programming for students with little or no programming experience.  Students learn how to program and how to use computational techniques to solve problems.  Topics include software design, algorithms, data analysis, and simulation techniques.  Assignments are done using the Python programming language. Meets with 6.0001 first half of term and 6.0002 second half of term. Credit cannot also be received for 6.0001 or 6.0002. Final given during final exam week.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Guttag</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Bell</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=6.00');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.0001"></a>
<p><h3>6.0001 Introduction to Computer Science Programming in Python
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-3-1
<br>Ends Mar 23. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-100</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to computer science and programming for students with little or no programming experience. Students develop skills to program and use computational techniques to solve problems. Topics include the notion of computation, Python, simple algorithms and data structures, testing and debugging, and algorithmic complexity. Combination of 6.0001 and 6.0002 counts as REST subject. Final given in the seventh week of the term.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Guttag</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Bell</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=6.0001');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.0002"></a>
<p><h3>6.0002 Introduction to Computational Thinking and Data Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.0001">6.0001</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-3-1
<br>Begins Apr 2. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-100</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to using computation to understand real-world phenomena. Topics include plotting, stochastic programs, probability and statistics, random walks, Monte Carlo simulations, modeling data, optimization problems, and clustering. Combination of 6.0001 and 6.0002 counts as REST subject. Final given during final exam week.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Guttag</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Bell</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=6.0002');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.002"></a>
<p><h3>6.002 Circuits and Electronics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m2a.html#2.087">2.087</a></I>
<br>Units: 4-1-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m6a.html#6.S064">6.S064</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-123</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i> <b>Recitation:</b> <i>WF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>) or <i>WF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>) or <i>WF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fundamentals of the lumped circuit abstraction. Resistive elements and networks, independent and dependent sources, switches and MOS devices, digital abstraction, amplifiers, and energy storage elements. Dynamics of first- and second-order networks; design in the time and frequency domains; analog and digital circuits and applications. Design exercises. Occasional laboratory.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Perreault</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Lang</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.S064"></a>
<p><h3>6.S064 Special Subject: Circuits and Electronics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m2a.html#2.087">2.087</a></I>
<br>Units: 0-0-12
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</A>
<br><a href="https://www.eecs.mit.edu/academics-admissions/academic-information/subject-updates-spring-2017/6s064-circuits-and-electronics">https://www.eecs.mit.edu/academics-admissions/academic-information/subject-updates-spring-2017/6s064-circuits-and-electronics</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Experimental version of 6.002 approved by the Committee on the Undergraduate Program, effective Fall 2016-Spring 2018.  Offered entirely online. See description of 6.002. Licensed as a REST by the Committee on Curricula, effective Spring 2017-Spring 2018.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.003"></a>
<p><h3>6.003 Signals and Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.087">2.087</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>
<br>Units: 2-4-6
<br><a href="http://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/6/fa17/6.003">http://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/6/fa17/6.003</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M12.30-2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-141</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>W12.30-2,F11-2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) or <i>W2-3.30,F2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents the fundamentals of signal and system analysis. Topics include discrete-time and continuous-time signals, Fourier series and transforms, Laplace and Z transforms, and analysis of linear, time-invariant systems. Applications drawn broadly from engineering and physics, including audio and image processing, communications, and automatic control.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Lim</I><br>Spring: <I>D. Freeman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.004"></a>
<p><h3>6.004 Computation Structures
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><a href="http://6004.mit.edu/">http://6004.mit.edu/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-123</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>WF10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-302</a>) or <i>WF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-302</a>) or <i>WF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-302</a>) or <i>WF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-302</a>) or <i>WF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-302</a>) or <i>WF3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-302</a>) or <i>WF10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-301</a>) or <i>WF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-301</a>) or <i>WF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>) or <i>WF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>) or <i>WF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>) or <i>WF3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces architecture of digital systems, emphasizing structural principles common to a wide range of technologies. Multilevel implementation strategies; definition of new primitives (e.g., gates, instructions, procedures, and processes) and their mechanization using lower-level elements. Analysis of potential concurrency; precedence constraints and performance measures; pipelined and multidimensional systems. Instruction set design issues; architectural support for contemporary software structures.
<br>Fall: <I>C. Terman</I><br>Spring: <I>C. Terman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.006"></a>
<p><h3>6.006 Introduction to Algorithms
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.042">6.042</a>; <a href="m6a.html#6.0001">6.0001</a> or <I>Coreq: <a href="m6a.html#6.009">6.009</a></I>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><a href="https://learning-modules.mit.edu/class/index.html?uuid=/course/6/sp18/6.006">https://learning-modules.mit.edu/class/index.html?uuid=/course/6/sp18/6.006</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-100</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>WF10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-153</a>) or <i>WF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-145</a>) or <i>WF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-308</a>) or <i>WF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-308</a>) or <i>WF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-153</a>) or <i>WF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-153</a>) or <i>WF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-153</a>) or <i>WF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-153</a>) or <i>WF3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-153</a>) or <i>WF4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-153</a>) or <i>WF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-314</a>) or <i>WF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-314</a>) or <i>WF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=13">13-5101</a>) or <i>WF3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=13">13-5101</a>) or <i>WF10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to mathematical modeling of computational problems, as well as common algorithms, algorithmic paradigms, and data structures used to solve these problems. Emphasizes the relationship between algorithms and programming, and introduces basic performance measures and analysis techniques for these problems.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Ku</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Ku</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.007"></a>
<p><h3>6.007 Electromagnetic Energy: From Motors to Solar Cells
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m2a.html#2.087">2.087</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-1-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Discusses applications of electromagnetic and equivalent quantum mechanical principles to classical and modern devices. Covers energy conversion and power flow in both macroscopic and quantum-scale electrical and electromechanical systems, including electric motors and generators, electric circuit elements, quantum tunneling structures and instruments. Studies photons as waves and particles and their interaction with matter in optoelectronic devices, including solar cells and displays.
<br><I>M. Baldo</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.008"></a>
<p><h3>6.008 Introduction to Inference
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-4-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces probabilistic modeling for problems of inference and machine learning from data, emphasizing analytical and computational aspects. Distributions, marginalization, conditioning, and structure; graphical representations. Belief propagation, decision-making, classification, estimation, and prediction. Sampling methods and analysis. Introduces asymptotic analysis and information measures. Computational laboratory component explores the concepts introduced in class in the context contemporary applications. Students design inference algorithms, investigate their behavior on real data, and discuss experimental results.
<br><I>G. Wornell</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.009"></a>
<p><h3>6.009 Fundamentals of Programming
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.0001">6.0001</a>
<br>Units: 2-4-6
<br><a href="https://6009.csail.mit.edu/">https://6009.csail.mit.edu/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-101</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>F9-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-370</a>) or <i>F10-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-270</a>) or <i>F1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-141</a>) or <i>F1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-370</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W9-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-100</a>) or <i>W10-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-159</a>) or <i>W1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-370</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-390</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces fundamental concepts of programming. Designed to develop skills in applying basic methods from programming languages to abstract problems. Topics include programming and Python basics, computational concepts, software engineering, algorithmic techniques, data types, and recursion and tail recursion. Lab component consists of software design, construction, and implementation of design.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Chlipala</I><br>Spring: <I>E. Demaine</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.01"></a>
<p><h3>6.01 Introduction to EECS via Robotics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.0001">6.0001</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-4-6
<br><a href="http://mit.edu/6.01/index.html">http://mit.edu/6.01/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-123</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>M11-12.30,W9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An integrated introduction to electrical engineering and computer science, taught using substantial laboratory experiments with mobile robots. Key issues in the design of engineered artifacts operating in the natural world: measuring and modeling system behaviors; assessing errors in sensors and effectors; specifying tasks; designing solutions based on analytical and computational models; planning, executing, and evaluating experimental tests of performance; refining models and designs. Issues addressed in the context of computer programs, control systems, probabilistic inference problems, circuits and transducers, which all play important roles in achieving robust operation of a large variety of engineered systems.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Hartz</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Hartz</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.011"></a>
<p><h3>6.011 Signals, Systems and Inference
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>; <a href="m6a.html#6.008">6.008</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.041A">6.041A</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.600">18.600</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-123</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-303</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-303</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers signals, systems and inference in communication, control and signal processing. Topics include input-output and state-space models of linear systems driven by deterministic and random signals; time- and transform-domain representations in discrete and continuous time; and group delay. State feedback and observers. Probabilistic models; stochastic processes, correlation functions, power spectra, spectral factorization. Least-mean square error estimation; Wiener filtering. Hypothesis testing; detection; matched filters.
<br><I>G. Verghese</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=6.011');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.012"></a>
<p><h3>6.012 Microelectronic Devices and Circuits
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-155</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>WF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-303</a>) or <i>WF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-303</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Microelectronic device modeling, and basic microelectronic circuit analysis and design. Physical electronics of semiconductor junction and MOS devices. Relating terminal behavior to internal physical processes, developing circuit models, and understanding the uses and limitations of different models. Use of incremental and large-signal techniques to analyze and design transistor circuits, with examples chosen from digital circuits, linear amplifiers, and other integrated circuits. Design project.
<br>Fall: <I>M. Shulaker</I><br>Spring: <I>M. Shulaker</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.013"></a>
<p><h3>6.013 Electromagnetics and Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-5-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-144</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>T12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=38">38-601</a>) or <i>T1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=38">38-601</a>) or <i>T2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=38">38-601</a>) or <i>T3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=38">38-601</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-301</a>) or <i>R2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-303</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analysis and design of modern applications that employ electromagnetic phenomena for signals and power transmission in RF, microwaves, optical and wireless communication systems. Fundamentals include dynamic solutions for Maxwell's equations; electromagnetic power and energy, waves in media, metallic and dielectric waveguides, radiation, and diffraction; resonance; filters; and acoustic analogs. Labs activities range from building to testing of devices and systems (e.g., antenna arrays, radars, dielectric waveguides). Students work in teams on self-proposed maker-style design projects with a focus on fostering creativity, teamwork, and debugging skills. 6.002, 6.003 and 6.007 are recommended but not required.
<br><I>L. Daniel</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=6.013');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.02"></a>
<p><h3>6.02 Introduction to EECS via Communications Networks
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.0001">6.0001</a>
<br>Units: 4-4-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies key concepts, systems, and algorithms to reliably communicate data in settings ranging from the cellular phone network and the Internet to deep space. Weekly laboratory experiments explore these areas in depth. Topics presented in three modules - bits, signals, and packets - spanning the multiple layers of a communication system. Bits module includes information, entropy, data compression algorithms, and error correction with block and convolutional codes. Signals module includes modeling physical channels and noise, signal design, filtering and detection, modulation, and frequency-division multiplexing. Packets module includes switching and queuing principles, media access control, routing protocols, and data transport protocols.
<br><I>K. Lacurts</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.021"></a>
<p><h3>6.021[J] Cellular Neurophysiology and Computing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.791">2.791[J]</A>, <A HREF="m9a.html#9.21">9.21[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.370">20.370[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2b.html#2.794">2.794[J]</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.521">6.521[J]</A>, <A HREF="m9a.html#9.021">9.021[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.470">20.470[J]</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.541">HST.541[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.301">10.301</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-2-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Integrated overview of the biophysics of cells from prokaryotes to neurons, with a focus on mass transport and electrical signal generation across cell membrane. First third of course focuses on mass transport through membranes: diffusion, osmosis, chemically mediated, and active transport. Second third focuses on electrical properties of cells: ion transport to action potential generation and propagation in electrically excitable cells. Synaptic transmission. Electrical properties interpreted via kinetic and molecular properties of single voltage-gated ion channels. Final third focuses on biophysics of synaptic transmission and introduction to neural computing. Laboratory and computer exercises illustrate the concepts. Students taking graduate version complete different assignments. Preference to juniors and seniors.
<br><I>T. Heldt</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.022"></a>
<p><h3>6.022[J] Quantitative Systems Physiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.792">2.792[J]</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.542">HST.542[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2b.html#2.796">2.796[J]</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.522">6.522[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-2-6
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/6.022j/www/">http://web.mit.edu/6.022j/www/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-124</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-117</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-117</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Application of the principles of energy and mass flow to major human organ systems. Anatomical, physiological and clinical features of the cardiovascular, respiratory and renal systems. Mechanisms of regulation and homeostasis. Systems, features and devices that are most illuminated by the methods of physical sciences and engineering models. Required laboratory work includes animal studies. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>T. Heldt</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=6.022');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.023"></a>
<p><h3>6.023[J] Fields, Forces and Flows in Biological Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.793">2.793[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.330">20.330[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.021">6.021</a>, or permission of instructor, <I>Coreq: <a href="m20a.html#20.309">20.309</a></I>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-163</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-169</a>) or <i>T4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-167</a>) or <i>W12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-168</a>) or <i>R2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-191</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to electric fields, fluid flows, transport phenomena and their application to biological systems. Flux and continuity laws, Maxwell's equations, electro-quasistatics, electro-chemical-mechanical driving forces, conservation of mass and momentum, Navier-Stokes flows, and electrokinetics. Applications include biomolecular transport in tissues, electrophoresis, and microfluidics.
<br><I>A. Grodzinsky, S. Manalis</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.024"></a>
<p><h3>6.024[J] Molecular, Cellular, and Tissue Biomechanics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.797">2.797[J]</A>, <A HREF="m3a.html#3.053">3.053[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.310">20.310[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2b.html#2.370">2.370</a> or <a href="m2b.html#2.772">2.772J</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m3a.html#3.016">3.016</a>; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops and applies scaling laws and the methods of continuum mechanics to biomechanical phenomena over a range of length scales. Topics include structure of tissues and the molecular basis for macroscopic properties; chemical and electrical effects on mechanical behavior; cell mechanics, motility and adhesion; biomembranes; biomolecular mechanics and molecular motors. Experimental methods for probing structures at the tissue, cellular, and molecular levels.
<br><I>M. Bathe</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.025"></a>
<p><h3>6.025[J] Medical Device Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.750">2.750[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2b.html#2.75">2.75[J]</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.525">6.525[J]</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.552">HST.552[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.008">2.008</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.101">6.101</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.111">6.111</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.115">6.115</a>, <a href="m22a.html#22.071">22.071</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an intense project-based learning experience around the design of medical devices with foci ranging from mechanical to electro mechanical to electronics.  Projects motivated by real-world clinical challenges provided by sponsors and clinicians who also help mentor teams. Covers the design process, project management, and fundamentals of mechanical and electrical circuit and sensor design. Students work in small teams to execute a substantial term project, with emphasis placed upon developing creative designs - via a deterministic design process - that are developed and optimized using analytical techniques. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>A. Slocum</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.027"></a>
<p><h3>6.027[J] Biomolecular Feedback Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2a.html#2.180">2.180[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2a.html#2.18">2.18[J]</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.557">6.557[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Comprehensive introduction to dynamics and control of biomolecular systems with emphasis on design/analysis techniques from control theory. Provides a review of biology concepts, regulation mechanisms, and models. Covers basic enabling technologies, engineering principles for designing biological functions, modular design techniques, and design limitations. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.03"></a>
<p><h3>6.03 Introduction to EECS via Medical Technology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-4-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-101</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>R9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=38">38-530</a>) or <i>R2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=38">38-530</a>) or <i>F9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=38">38-530</a>) or <i>F2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=38">38-530</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores biomedical signals generated from electrocardiograms, glucose detectors or ultrasound images, and magnetic resonance images. Topics include physical characterization and modeling of systems in the time and frequency domains; analog and digital signals and noise; basic machine learning including decision trees, clustering, and classification; and introductory machine vision. Labs designed to strengthen background in signal processing and machine learning. Students design and run structured experiments, and develop and test procedures through further experimentation.
<br><I>C. Stultz</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.031"></a>
<p><h3>6.031 Elements of Software Construction
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.009">6.009</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-10
<br><a href="http://mit.edu/6.031">http://mit.edu/6.031</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-101</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces fundamental principles and techniques of software development: how to write software that is safe from bugs, easy to understand, and ready for change. Topics include specifications and invariants; testing, test-case generation, and coverage; abstract data types and representation independence; design patterns for object-oriented programming; concurrent programming, including message passing and shared concurrency, and defending against races and deadlock; and functional programming with immutable data and higher-order functions. Includes weekly programming exercises and larger group programming projects.
<br>Fall: <I>M. Goldman</I><br>Spring: <I>M. Goldman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.033"></a>
<p><h3>6.033 Computer System Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.004">6.004</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.009">6.009</a>
<br>Units: 5-1-6
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/6.033">http://web.mit.edu/6.033</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-100</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-301</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-156</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-442</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-442</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-233</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-233</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-301</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-121</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-121</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-379</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-379</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-156</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-304</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-304</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-372</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-372</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-372</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-155</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-302</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-310</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-310</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-144</a>) or <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-302</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-168</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-372</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-302</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-168</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-304</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-302</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-304</a>) or <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-304</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-304</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=38">38-166</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=38">38-166</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics on the engineering of computer software and hardware systems: techniques for controlling complexity; strong modularity using client-server design, operating systems; performance, networks; naming; security and privacy; fault-tolerant systems, atomicity and coordination of concurrent activities, and recovery; impact of computer systems on society.  Case studies of working systems and readings from the current literature provide comparisons and contrasts.  Includes a single, semester-long design project.  Students engage in extensive written communication exercises. Enrollment may be limited.
<br><I>K. Lacurts</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=6.033');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.034"></a>
<p><h3>6.034 Artificial Intelligence
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.0001">6.0001</a>
<br>Units: 4-3-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces representations, methods, and architectures used to build applications and to account for human intelligence from a computational point of view. Covers applications of rule chaining, constraint propagation, constrained search, inheritance, statistical inference, and other problem-solving paradigms. Also addresses applications of identification trees, neural nets, genetic algorithms, support-vector machines, boosting, and other learning paradigms. Considers what separates human intelligence from that of other animals.
<br><I>P. Winston</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.035"></a>
<p><h3>6.035 Computer Language Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.004">6.004</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.031">6.031</a>
<br>Units: 4-4-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analyzes issues associated with the implementation of higher-level programming languages. Fundamental concepts, functions, and structures of compilers. The interaction of theory and practice. Using tools in building software. Includes a multi-person project on compiler design and implementation.
<br><I>M. Carbin</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.036"></a>
<p><h3>6.036 Introduction to Machine Learning
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.862">6.862</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.0001">6.0001</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-100</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) or <i>T1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) or <i>T2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) or <i>R9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) or <i>R11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) or <i>R1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) or <i>R2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces principles, algorithms, and applications of machine learning from the point of view of modeling and prediction; formulation of learning problems; representation, over-fitting, generalization; clustering, classification, probabilistic modeling; and methods such as support vector machines, hidden Markov models, and Bayesian networks. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Meets with 6.862 when offered concurrently. Enrollment may be limited.
<br>Fall: <I>L. Kaelbling</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Kaelbling</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.037"></a>
<p><h3>6.037 Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-5 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies the structure and interpretation of computer programs which transcend specific programming languages. Demonstrates thought patterns for computer science using Scheme. Includes weekly programming projects. Enrollment may be limited.
<br><I>A. Hunter</I><br>No textbook information available

<a name="6.041A"></a>
<p><h3>6.041A Introduction to Probability I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6b.html#6.431A">6.431A</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br>Ends Mar 23. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-370</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-156</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-156</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to probability theory and the modeling and analysis of probabilistic systems. Probabilistic models, conditional probability. Discrete and continuous random variables. Expectation and conditional expectation. Limit Theorems. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Combination of 6.041A and 6.041B counts as a REST subject.
<br>Fall: <I>P. Jaillet</I><br>Spring: <I>G. Bresler</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.041B"></a>
<p><h3>6.041B Introduction to Probability II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6b.html#6.431B">6.431B</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041A">6.041A</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br>Begins Apr 2. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-370</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-156</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-156</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Continuation of 6.041A. Further topics about random variables. Bayesian estimation and hypothesis testing. Elements of statistical inference. Bernoulli and Poisson processes. Markov chains. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.  Combination of 6.041A and 6.041B counts as a REST subject.
<br>Fall: <I>P. Jaillet</I><br>Spring: <I>G. Bresler</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.042"></a>
<p><h3>6.042[J] Mathematics for Computer Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m18a.html#18.062">18.062[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><a href="https://courses.csail.mit.edu/6.042/spring18/">https://courses.csail.mit.edu/6.042/spring18/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-082</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-044</a>) or <i>MWF2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-044</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-124</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Elementary discrete mathematics for computer science and engineering. Emphasis on mathematical definitions and proofs as well as on applicable methods.  Topics include formal logic notation, proof methods; induction, well-ordering; sets, relations; elementary graph theory; asymptotic notation and growth of functions; permutations and combinations, counting principles; discrete probability.  Further selected topics include recursive definition and structural induction, state machines and invariants, integer congruences, recurrences, generating functions.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Meyer</I><br>Spring: <I>Z. Abel</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.045"></a>
<p><h3>6.045[J] Automata, Computability, and Complexity
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m18a.html#18.400">18.400[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.042">6.042</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.400">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.400</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-155</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Mathematical introduction to questions concerning the definition of computation, and what problems can be solved by computers. Considers what problems can be efficiently solved by way of finite automata, circuits, Turing machines, and communication complexity. Provides complete, rigorous answers to the questions in some cases; others are major open problems. Builds skills in classifying computational problems in terms of their difficulty. Discusses other fundamental issues, including the Church-Turing Thesis, the P versus NP problem, and the power of randomness.
<br><I>R. Rubinfeld</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.046"></a>
<p><h3>6.046[J] Design and Analysis of Algorithms
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m18a.html#18.410">18.410[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.006">6.006</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><a href="https://learning-modules.mit.edu/class/index.html?uuid=/course/6/fa17/6.046J#info">https://learning-modules.mit.edu/class/index.html?uuid=/course/6/fa17/6.046J#info</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-101</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-168</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-168</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-168</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Techniques for the design and analysis of efficient algorithms, emphasizing methods useful in practice. Topics include sorting; search trees, heaps, and hashing; divide-and-conquer; dynamic programming; greedy algorithms; amortized analysis; graph algorithms; and shortest paths. Advanced topics may include network flow; computational geometry; number-theoretic algorithms; polynomial and matrix calculations; caching; and parallel computing.
<br>Fall: <I>V. Vassilevska Williams</I><br>Spring: <I>B. Tidor</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=6.046');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.047"></a>
<p><h3>6.047 Computational Biology: Genomes, Networks, Evolution
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.878">6.878[J]</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.507">HST.507[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.006">6.006</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the algorithmic and machine learning foundations of computational biology, combining theory with practice. Principles of algorithm design, influential problems and techniques, and analysis of large-scale biological datasets. Topics include (a) genomes: sequence analysis, gene finding, RNA folding, genome alignment and assembly, database search; (b) networks: gene expression analysis, regulatory motifs, biological network analysis; (c) evolution: comparative genomics, phylogenetics, genome duplication, genome rearrangements, evolutionary theory.  These are coupled with fundamental algorithmic techniques including: dynamic programming, hashing, Gibbs sampling, expectation maximization, hidden Markov models, stochastic context-free grammars, graph clustering, dimensionality reduction, Bayesian networks.
<br><I>M. Kellis</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.049"></a>
<p><h3>6.049[J] Evolutionary Biology:  Concepts, Models and Computation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.33">7.33[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>; <a href="m6a.html#6.0001">6.0001</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores and illustrates how evolution explains biology, with an emphasis on computational model building for analyzing evolutionary data.  Covers key concepts of biological evolution, including adaptive evolution, neutral evolution, evolution of sex, genomic conflict, speciation, phylogeny and comparative methods, life's history, coevolution, human evolution, and evolution of disease.
<br><I>R. Berwick, D. Bartel</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.050"></a>
<p><h3>6.050[J] Information, Entropy, and Computation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2a.html#2.110">2.110[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the ultimate limits to communication and computation, with an emphasis on the physical nature of information and information processing. Topics include information and computation, digital signals, codes, and compression. Biological representations of information. Logic circuits, computer architectures, and algorithmic information. Noise, probability, and error correction. The concept of entropy applied to channel capacity and to the second law of thermodynamics. Reversible and irreversible operations and the physics of computation. Quantum computation.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.057"></a>
<p><h3>6.057 Introduction to MATLAB
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Accelerated introduction to MATLAB and its popular toolboxes. Lectures are interactive, with students conducting sample MATLAB problems in real time. Includes problem-based MATLAB assignments. Students must provide their own laptop and software. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>A. Hunter</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.058"></a>
<p><h3>6.058 Introduction to Signals and Systems, and Feedback Control
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-2-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces fundamental concepts for 6.003, including Fourier and Laplace transforms, convolution, sampling, filters, feedback control, stability, and Bode plots. Students engage in problem solving, using Mathematica and MATLAB software extensively to help visualize processing in the time frequency domains.
<br><I>A. Hunter</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.061"></a>
<p><h3>6.061 Introduction to Electric Power Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6b.html#6.690">6.690</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.013">6.013</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Electric circuit theory with application to power handling electric circuits. Modeling and behavior of electromechanical devices, including magnetic circuits, motors, and generators. Operational fundamentals of synchronous. Interconnection of generators and motors with electric power transmission and distribution circuits. Power generation, including alternative and sustainable sources. Incorporation of energy storage in power systems. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>J. L. Kirtley, Jr.</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.070"></a>
<p><h3>6.070[J] Electronics Project Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.120">EC.120[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-2-2
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-409</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intuition-based introduction to electronics, electronic components and test equipment such as oscilloscopes, meters (voltage, resistance inductance, capacitance, etc.), and signal generators. Emphasizes individual instruction and development of skills, such as soldering, assembly, and troubleshooting. Students design, build, and keep a small electronics project to put their new knowledge into practice. Intended for students with little or no previous background in electronics. Enrollment may be limited.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Bales</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Bales</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.072"></a>
<p><h3>6.072[J] Introduction to Digital Electronics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.110">EC.110[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 0-3-3 [P/D/F]
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i> <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Design your own circuits for times when off-the-shelf solutions are not available. Seminar begins with assembly of a utility board. Weekly labs cover digital logic gates, memory elements, and finite-state machine design. Seminar concludes with a team-based design project. Preference given to freshmen. Maximum of 10 students per term, lottery at the first class session if oversubscribed .
<br><I>J. Bales</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.073"></a>
<p><h3>6.073[J] Creating Video Games
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.611">CMS.611[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.01">6.01</a>, <a href="mCMSa.html#CMS.301">CMS.301</a>, or <a href="mCMSa.html#CMS.608">CMS.608</a>
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M1-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-117</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>W1-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-117</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces students to the complexities of working in small, multidisciplinary teams to develop video games. Covers creative design and production methods, stressing design iteration and regular testing across all aspects of game development (design, visual arts, music, fiction, and programming). Assumes a familiarity with current video games, and the ability to discuss games critically. Previous experience in audio design, visual arts, or project management recommended. Limited to 24.
<br><I>P. Tan, S. Verrilli, R. Eberhardt</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.08"></a>
<p><h3>6.08 Introduction to EECS via Interconnected Embedded Systems
<br>(6.S08)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a></I>
<br>Units: 1-5-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=54">54-100</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>T11-12.30,R9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=38">38-530</a>) or <i>T2-3.30,R2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=38">38-530</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to embedded systems in the context of connected devices, wearables and the "Internet of Things" (IoT). Topics include microcontrollers, energy utilization, algorithmic efficiency, interfacing with sensors, networking, cryptography, and local versus distributed computation. Students design, make, and program an internet-connected wearable or handheld device. In final project, student teams design and demo their own cloud-connected IoT system. Enrollment limited; preference to first- and second-year students.
<br><I>J. Steinmeyer</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
