<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 7: Biology<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="https://biology.mit.edu/"><i>Course 7 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course7.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=7&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+++7&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>7.00-7.999 plus UROP and Thesis</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>Undergraduate Subjects</h2>
<h3><br>Introductory Biology</h3>
<p>All five subjects cover the same core material, comprising about 50% of the course, while the remaining material is specialized for each version as described below.  Core material includes fundamental principles of biochemistry, genetics, molecular biology, and cell biology.  These topics address structure and regulation of genes, structure and synthesis of proteins, how these molecules are integrated into cells and how cells communicate with one another.
<a name="7.012"></a>
<p><h3>7.012 Introductory Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/bio.gif" alt="Biology" title="Biology" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m7a.html#7.013">7.013</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.014">7.014</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.015">7.015</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.016">7.016</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.7012">ES.7012</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.7013">ES.7013</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Exploration into areas of current research in molecular and cell biology, immunology, neurobiology, human genetics, biochemistry, and evolution. Enrollment limited to seating capacity of classroom. Admittance may be controlled by lottery.
<br><I>E. Lander, R. Weinberg</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.013"></a>
<p><h3>7.013 Introductory Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/bio.gif" alt="Biology" title="Biology" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m7a.html#7.012">7.012</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.014">7.014</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.015">7.015</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.016">7.016</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.7012">ES.7012</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.7013">ES.7013</A>
<br><a href="https://biology.mit.edu/undergraduate/course-requirements/general-institute-requirement/">https://biology.mit.edu/undergraduate/course-requirements/general-institute-requirement/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-100</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-180</a>) or <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-180</a>) or <i>MW1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>) or <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) or <i>MW3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) or <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>) or <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>) or <i>TR3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Genomic approaches to human biology, including neuroscience, development, immunology, tissue repair and stem cells, tissue engineering, and infectious and inherited diseases, including cancer. Enrollment limited to seating capacity of classroom. Admittance may be controlled by lottery.
<br><I>A. Amon, H. Sive</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=7.013');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.014"></a>
<h3>7.014 Introductory Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/bio.gif" alt="Biology" title="Biology" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m7a.html#7.012">7.012</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.013">7.013</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.015">7.015</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.016">7.016</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.7012">ES.7012</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.7013">ES.7013</A>
<br><a href="https://biology.mit.edu/undergraduate/course-requirements/general-institute-requirement/">https://biology.mit.edu/undergraduate/course-requirements/general-institute-requirement/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-111</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-302</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-302</a>) or <i>TR3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-156</a>) or <i>TR4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-156</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies the fundamental principles of biology and their application towards understanding the Earth as a dynamical system shaped by life. Focuses on molecular ecology in order to show how processes at the molecular level can illuminate macroscopic properties, including evolution and maintenance of biogeochemical cycles, and ecological interactions in ecosystems ranging from the ocean to the human gut. Includes quantitative analysis of population growth, community structure, competition, mutualism and predation; highlights their role in shaping the biosphere. Enrollment limited to seating capacity of classroom. Admittance may be controlled by lottery.
<br><I>G. C. Walker, S. W. Chisholm, M. Polz</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=7.014');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.015"></a>
<p><h3>7.015 Introductory Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/bio.gif" alt="Biology" title="Biology" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: High school course covering cellular and molecular biology, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m7a.html#7.012">7.012</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.013">7.013</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.014">7.014</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.016">7.016</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.7012">ES.7012</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.7013">ES.7013</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Emphasizes the application of fundamental biological principles to modern, trending topics in biology. Specific modules focus on antibiotic resistance, the microbiome, biotechnology (e.g., genetically-modified organisms and CRISPR-based genome editing), personal genetics and genomics, neurodegenerative diseases, and metabolism (the science behind making wine, cheese, and natural product drugs). Includes discussion of the social and ethical issues surrounding modern biology. Limited to 60; admittance may be controlled by lottery.
<br><I>M. Laub, J. K. Weng</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.016"></a>
<p><h3>7.016 Introductory Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/bio.gif" alt="Biology" title="Biology" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m7a.html#7.012">7.012</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.013">7.013</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.014">7.014</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.015">7.015</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.7012">ES.7012</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.7013">ES.7013</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to fundamental principles of biochemistry, molecular biology and genetics for understanding the functions of living systems. Covers examples of the use of chemical biology, the use of genetics in biological discovery, principles of cellular organization and communication, and engineering biological systems.  In addition, includes 21st-century molecular genetics in understanding human health and therapeutic intervention. Enrollment limited to seating capacity of classroom. Admittance may be controlled by lottery.
<br><I>B. Imperiali, A. Martin</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.02"></a>
<p><h3>7.02[J] Introduction to Experimental Biology and Communication
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m10a.html#10.702">10.702[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-8-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-105</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-074</a>) or <i>WF1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-074</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-150</a>) or <i>T9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-148</a>) or <i>W9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-121</a>) or <i>W1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-148</a>) or <i>M9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-121</a>) or <i>M1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-148</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the experimental concepts and methods of molecular biology, biochemistry, and genetic analysis. Emphasis on experimental design, critical data analysis, and the development of written communications skills. 12 units may be applied to the General Institute Laboratory Requirement. Enrollment limited.
<br>Fall: <I>T. Baker, M. Gehring, K.D. Wittrup</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Boyer; O. Yilmaz, K.D. Wittrup</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.03"></a>
<p><h3>7.03 Genetics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-155</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>) or <i>M2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>) or <i>M3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>) or <i>T10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=38">38-166</a>) or <i>T11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>) or <i>T12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>The principles of genetics with application to the study of biological function at the level of molecules, cells, and multicellular organisms, including humans. Structure and function of genes, chromosomes, and genomes. Biological variation resulting from recombination, mutation, and selection. Population genetics. Use of genetic methods to analyze protein function, gene regulation, and inherited disease.
<br>Fall: <I>P. Gupta, P. Reddien</I><br>Spring: <I>M. Hemann, A. Regev</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=7.03');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.05"></a>
<p><h3>7.05 General Biochemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.12">5.12</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.507">20.507</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-250</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-322</a>) or <i>T12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-322</a>) or <i>T4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) or <i>T EVE (7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) or <i>W1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) or <i>R11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-121</a>) or <i>R EVE (7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>) or <i>M3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>) or <i>R2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-302</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Contributions of biochemistry toward an understanding of the structure and functioning of organisms, tissues, and cells. Chemistry and functions of constituents of cells and tissues and the chemical and physical-chemical basis for the structures of nucleic acids, proteins, and carbohydrates. Basic enzymology and biochemical reaction mechanisms involved in macromolecular synthesis and degradation, signaling, transport, and movement. General metabolism of carbohydrates, fats, and nitrogen-containing materials such as amino acids, proteins, and related compounds.
<br><I>M. Vander Heiden, M. Yaffe</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=7.05');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.06"></a>
<p><h3>7.06 Cell Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-270</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-302</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-302</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-302</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents the biology of cells of higher organisms.  Studies the structure, function, and biosynthesis of cellular membranes and organelles; cell growth and oncogenic transformation; transport, receptors, and cell signaling; the cytoskeleton, the extracellular matrix, and cell movements; cell division and cell cycle; functions of specialized cell types.  Emphasizes the current molecular knowledge of cell biological processes as well as the genetic, biochemical, and other experimental approaches that resulted in these discoveries.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Martin, F. Solomon</I><br>Spring: <I>I. Cheeseman, T. Schwartz</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=7.06');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.08"></a>
<p><h3>7.08[J] Biological Chemistry II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m5a.html#5.08">5.08[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.80">7.80</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.12">5.12</a>; <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a> or <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-105</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-251</a>) or <i>R1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-251</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-251</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-251</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>More advanced treatment of biochemical mechanisms that underlie biological processes.  Topics include macromolecular machines such as the ribosome, the proteosome, fatty acid synthases as a paradigm for polyketide synthases and non-ribosomal polypeptide synthases, and polymerases. Emphasis is on experimental methods used to unravel these processes and how these processes fit into the cellular context and coordinate regulation.
<br><I>E. Nolan, R. Raines</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.09"></a>
<p><h3>7.09 Quantitative and Computational Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-261</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Quantitative and computational analysis of biological systems at the molecular and cellular level.  Includes models of biological processes across different time scales, from steady-state to kinetics of gene expression, circadian clock, cell growth, and evolutionary dynamics. Methods include physical, systems, and synthetic biology. Also covers second-generation sequencing technologies, and topics in computational analysis of genomes, including sequence alignment, motif finding, information theory and RNA secondary structure prediction.
<br><I>C. Burge, G. W. Li</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=7.09');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.102"></a>
<p><h3>7.102 Laboratory in Molecular Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/PartLab.gif" alt="Partial Lab" title="Partial Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 0-5-1
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces basic methods of experimental molecular biology. Specific experiments vary from year-to-year, but will focus on the molecular genetic characterization of fundamental biological processes. Biology GIR or Chemistry GIR recommended. Satisfies 6 units of Institute Laboratory credit. Limited to 24; admittance may be controlled by lottery.
<br><I>D. Kim</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.11"></a>
<p><h3>7.11 Biology Teaching
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For qualified undergraduate students interested in gaining some experience in teaching. Laboratory, tutorial, or classroom teaching under the supervision of a faculty member. Students selected by interview.
<br>Fall: <I>Staff</I><br>Spring: <I>Staff</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.18"></a>
<p><h3>7.18 Topics in Experimental Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.19">7.19</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.02">7.02</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>, and an approved research experience; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-16-10
<br><a href="https://biology.mit.edu/undergraduate/current-students/subject-offerings/7-18-topics-in-experimental-biology/">https://biology.mit.edu/undergraduate/current-students/subject-offerings/7-18-topics-in-experimental-biology/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-156</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Independent experimental study under the direction of a member of the Biology Department faculty. Allows students with a strong interest in independent research to fulfill the project laboratory requirement for the Biology Department Program in the context of a research laboratory at MIT. The research must be conducted on the MIT campus and be a continuation of a previous 12-unit UROP project or full-time work over the summer. Written and oral presentation of the research results is required. Journal club discussions are used to help students evaluate and write scientific papers. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication is provided. Permission of the faculty research supervisor and the Biology Education Office must be obtained in advance.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Chen, A.J. Sinskey</I><br>Spring: <I>C. Kaiser</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.19"></a>
<p><h3>7.19 Communication in Experimental Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.18">7.18</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.02">7.02</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-4-4
<br><a href="https://biology.mit.edu/undergraduate/current-students/subject-offerings/7-18-topics-in-experimental-biology/">https://biology.mit.edu/undergraduate/current-students/subject-offerings/7-18-topics-in-experimental-biology/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-156</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students carry out independent literature research. Meets with the seminar and writing tutorial portions of 7.18. Journal club discussions are used to help students evaluate and write scientific papers. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication is provided. Permission of the instructor and the Biology Education Office must be obtained in advance.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Chen, A.J. Sinskey</I><br>Spring: <I>C. Kaiser</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.20"></a>
<p><h3>7.20[J] Human Physiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.540">HST.540[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Comprehensive exploration of human physiology, emphasizing the molecular basis and applied aspects of organ function and regulation in health and disease. Includes a review of cell structure and function, as well as the mechanisms by which the endocrine and nervous systems integrate cellular metabolism. Special emphasis on examining the cardiovascular, pulmonary, gastrointestinal, and renal systems, as well as liver function, drug metabolism, and pharmacogenetics.
<br><I>M. Krieger, D. Sabatini</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.21"></a>
<p><h3>7.21 Microbial Physiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.62">7.62</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Biochemical properties of bacteria and other microorganisms that enable them to grow under a variety of conditions. Interaction between bacteria and bacteriophages. Genetic and metabolic regulation of enzyme action and enzyme formation. Structure and function of components of the bacterial cell envelope. Protein secretion with a special emphasis on its various roles in pathogenesis. Additional topics include bioenergetics, symbiosis, quorum sensing, global responses to DNA damage, and biofilms.  Students taking the graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>G. C. Walker, A. J. Sinskey</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.22"></a>
<p><h3>7.22 Developmental Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics include development of animal body plans, tissue patterning, cell type determination, organogenesis, morphogenesis, stem cells, and the evolution of developmental diversity and processes. Covers experimental approaches to problems of development and evolution, such as the study of vertebrate (mouse, chick, frog, fish) and invertebrate (fly, worm) models.
<br><I>R. O. Hynes, P. Reddien</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.23"></a>
<p><h3>7.23 Immunology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.63">7.63</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Comprehensive survey of molecular, genetic, and cellular aspects of the immune system. Topics include innate and adaptive immunity; cells and organs of the immune system; immunoglobulin, T cell receptor, and major histocompatibility complex (MHC) proteins and genes; development and functions of B and T lymphocytes; immune responses to infections and tumors; hypersensitivity, autoimmunity, and immunodeficiencies. Particular attention to the development and function of the immune system as a whole, as studied by modern methods and techniques. Students taking the graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.26"></a>
<p><h3>7.26 Molecular Basis of Infectious Disease
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.66">7.66</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-117</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-574</a>) or <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-156</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-142</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the principles of host-pathogen interactions with an emphasis on infectious diseases of humans. Presents key concepts of pathogenesis through the study of various human pathogens. Includes critical analysis and discussion of assigned readings.  Students taking the graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>D. Kim</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.27"></a>
<p><h3>7.27 Principles of Human Disease
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-154</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) or <i>F9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers current understanding of and modern approaches to human disease, emphasizing the molecular and cellular basis of both genetic disease and cancer. Topics include the genetics of simple and complex traits; karyotypic analysis and positional cloning; genetic diagnosis; the roles of oncogenes and tumor suppressors in tumor initiation, progression, and treatment; the interaction between genetics and environment; animal models of human disease; cancer; aging and disease; and conventional and gene therapy treatment strategies.
<br><I>D. Housman, L. Guarente</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.28"></a>
<p><h3>7.28 Molecular Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.58">7.58</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-270</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) or <i>W1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) or <i>W11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-169</a>) or <i>W EVE (7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) or <i>M 10-11</i> <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Detailed analysis of the biochemical mechanisms that control the maintenance, expression, and evolution of prokaryotic and eukaryotic genomes. Topics covered in lecture and readings of relevant literature include: gene regulation, DNA replication, genetic recombination, and mRNA translation. Logic of experimental design and data analysis emphasized. Presentations include both lectures and group discussions of representative papers from the literature. Students taking the graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>U. RajBhandary, E. Calo</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=7.28');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.29"></a>
<p><h3>7.29[J] Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.09">9.09[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a> or <a href="m9a.html#9.01">9.01</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-3310</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-1015</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the structure and function of the nervous system. Emphasizes the cellular properties of neurons and other excitable cells. Includes the structure and biophysical properties of excitable cells, synaptic transmission, neurochemistry, neurodevelopment, integration of information in simple systems, and detection and information coding during sensory transduction.
<br><I>T. Littleton, M. Wilson</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=7.29');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.30A"></a>
<p><h3>7.30A[J] Fundamentals of Ecology I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); first half of term
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1a.html#1.018A">1.018A[J]</A>, <A HREF="m12a.html#12.031A">12.031A[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fundamentals of ecology, considering Earth as an integrated dynamic living system. Coevolution of the biosphere and geosphere, biogeochemical cycles, metabolic diversity, primary productivity, competition and the niche, trophic dynamics and food webs, population growth and limiting factors. Combination of 1.018A and 1.018B counts as REST subject.
<br><I>O. Cordero Sanchez</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.30B"></a>
<p><h3>7.30B[J] Fundamentals of Ecology II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); second half of term
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1a.html#1.018B">1.018B[J]</A>, <A HREF="m12a.html#12.031B">12.031B[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m1a.html#1.018A">1.018A</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced topics in Ecology. Population modeling, global carbon cycle, climate change, geoengineering, theories of resource competition and mutualism, allometric scaling, ecological genomics, niche theory, human population growth. Applied ecology. Combination of 1.018A and 1.018B counts as REST subject.
<br><I>O. Cordero Sanchez</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.31"></a>
<p><h3>7.31 Current Topics in Mammalian Biology: Medical Implications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers recent advances in mammalian cell and developmental biology with particular emphasis on approaches that utilize mouse genetics. Combines formal lectures on selected topics with readings of original papers which are discussed in class. Major emphasis on the implications of mechanisms of human genetic diseases. Topics include early mammalian development; genomic imprinting; X inactivation; embryonic stem cells; nuclear reprogramming of somatic cells; cell migration; nervous system development; and central nervous system degenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's and Huntington's disease. Limited to 20.
<br><I>F. Gertler, R. Jaenisch</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.32"></a>
<p><h3>7.32 Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.81">7.81[J]</A>, <A HREF="m8b.html#8.591">8.591[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.05">18.05</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to cellular and population-level systems biology with an emphasis on synthetic biology, modeling of genetic networks, cell-cell interactions, and evolutionary dynamics.  Cellular systems include genetic switches and oscillators, network motifs, genetic network evolution, and cellular decision-making.  Population-level systems include models of pattern formation, cell-cell communications, and evolutionary systems biology.  Students taking graduate version explore the subject in more depth.
<br><I>J. Gore</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.33"></a>
<p><h3>7.33[J] Evolutionary Biology:  Concepts, Models and Computation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.049">6.049[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>; <a href="m6a.html#6.0001">6.0001</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores and illustrates how evolution explains biology, with an emphasis on computational model building for analyzing evolutionary data.  Covers key concepts of biological evolution, including adaptive evolution, neutral evolution, evolution of sex, genomic conflict, speciation, phylogeny and comparative methods, life's history, coevolution, human evolution, and evolution of disease.
<br><I>R. Berwick, D. Bartel</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.331"></a>
<p><h3>7.331[J] Infections and Inequalities: Interdisciplinary Perspectives on Global Health
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.331">21A.331[J]</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.431">HST.431[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines case studies in infectious disease outbreaks to demonstrate how human health is a product of multiple determinants, such as biology, sociocultural and historical factors, politics, economic processes, and the environment. Analyzes how structural inequalities render certain populations vulnerable to illness and explores the moral and ethical dimensions of public health and clinical interventions to promote health. Limited to 25.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.340"></a><a name="7.341"></a><a name="7.342"></a><a name="7.343"></a><a name="7.344"></a>
<p><h3>7.340-7.344 Advanced Undergraduate Seminar
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a> or <a href="m7a.html#7.28">7.28</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>7.340:</b> <a href="https://biology-dev.mit.edu/undergraduate/current-students/subject-offerings/advanced-undergraduate-seminars/">https://biology-dev.mit.edu/undergraduate/current-students/subject-offerings/advanced-undergraduate-seminars/</a><br><b>7.344:</b> <a href="https://biology-dev.mit.edu/undergraduate/current-students/subject-offerings/advanced-undergraduate-seminars/">https://biology-dev.mit.edu/undergraduate/current-students/subject-offerings/advanced-undergraduate-seminars/</a>
<br><b>7.340:</b> TBA. <!--s--><br><b>7.341:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>W11-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-150</a>)<!--s--><br><b>7.342:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>T1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-150</a>)<!--s--><br><b>7.343:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>W3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-150</a>)<!--s--><br><b>7.344:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>R1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-150</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminars covering topics of current interest in biology with a focus on how to understand experimental methods and design and how to critically read the primary research literature. Small class size facilitates discussions and interactions with an active research scientist. Students visit research laboratories to see firsthand how biological research is conducted. Contact Biology Education Office for topics.
<br>Fall: <I>H. R. Horvitz</I><br>Spring: <I>H. R. Horvitz</I><br><b>7.340:</b> No required or recommended textbooks<br><b>7.341:</b> No required or recommended textbooks<br><b>7.342:</b> No required or recommended textbooks<br><b>7.343:</b> No required or recommended textbooks<br><b>7.344:</b> No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.345"></a><a name="7.346"></a><a name="7.347"></a><a name="7.348"></a><a name="7.349"></a>
<p><h3>7.345-7.349 Advanced Undergraduate Seminar
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a> or <a href="m7a.html#7.28">7.28</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>7.349:</b> <a href="https://biology-dev.mit.edu/undergraduate/current-students/subject-offerings/advanced-undergraduate-seminars/">https://biology-dev.mit.edu/undergraduate/current-students/subject-offerings/advanced-undergraduate-seminars/</a>
<br><b>7.345:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>W11-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-156</a>)<!--s--><br><b>7.346:</b> TBA. <!--s--><br><b>7.347:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>F11-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-150</a>)<!--s--><br><b>7.348:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>F1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-150</a>)<!--s--><br><b>7.349:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>M11-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-150</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminars covering topics of current interest in biology with a focus on how to understand experimental methods and design and how to critically read the primary research literature. Small class size facilitates discussions and interactions with an active research scientist. Students visit research laboratories to see firsthand how biological research is conducted. Contact Biology Education Office for topics.
<br>Fall: <I>H. R. Horvitz</I><br>Spring: <I>H. R. Horvitz</I><br><b>7.345:</b> No required or recommended textbooks<br><b>7.346:</b> No required or recommended textbooks<br><b>7.347:</b> No required or recommended textbooks<br><b>7.348:</b> No required or recommended textbooks<br><b>7.349:</b> No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.37"></a>
<p><h3>7.37[J] Molecular and Engineering Aspects of Biotechnology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m10a.html#10.441">10.441[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.361">20.361[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.012">3.012</a>, <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>, or <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>; <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m7a.html#7.371">7.371</A>
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/7.37j/">http://web.mit.edu/7.37j/</a>
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i>  <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers biological and bioengineering principles underlying the development and therapeutic use of recombinant proteins and stem cells; glycoengineering of recombinant proteins; normal and pathological signaling by growth factors and their receptors; receptor trafficking; monoclonal antibodies as therapeutics; protein pharmacology and delivery; stem cell-derived tissues as therapeutics; RNA therapeutics; combinatorial protein engineering; and new antitumor drugs.
<br><I>H. Lodish, L. Griffith</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.371"></a>
<p><h3>7.371 Biological and Engineering Principles Underlying Novel Biotherapeutics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m7a.html#7.37">7.37</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.441">10.441</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.361">20.361</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers biological and bioengineering principles underlying the development and therapeutic use of recombinant proteins and immune cells. Special attention to monoclonal antibodies and engineered immune system cells as therapeutics; protein- and glyco- engineering to enhance protein function; protein pharmacology and delivery; nucleic acid- based biotherapeutics; generation of functional cells and tissues from embryonic stem cells and iPS cells; and immune cell-cancer cell interactions in cancer immunotherapy.
<br><I>J. Chen, H. Lodish</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.41"></a>
<p><h3>7.41 Principles of Chemical Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.73">7.73</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Spanning the fields of biology, chemistry and engineering, class addresses the principles of chemical biology and its application of chemical and physical methods and reagents to the study and manipulation of biological systems. Topics include bioorthogonal reactions and activity-based protein profiling, small molecule inhibitors and chemical genetics, fluorescent probes for biological studies, and unnatural amino acid mutagenesis. Also covers chemical biology approaches for studying dynamic post-translational modification reactions, natural product biosynthesis and mutasynthesis, and high-throughput drug screening.  Students taking the graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth
<br><I>B. Imperiali</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.45"></a>
<p><h3>7.45 The Hallmarks of Cancer
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.85">7.85</A>)
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a></I>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a comprehensive introduction to the fundamentals of cancer biology and cancer treatment. Topics include cancer genetics, genomics, and epigenetics; familial cancer syndromes; signal transduction, cell cycle control, and apoptosis; cancer metabolism; stem cells and cancer; metastasis; cancer immunology and immunotherapy; conventional and molecularly-targeted therapies; and early detection and prevention. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>T. Jacks, M. Vander Heiden</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.458"></a>
<p><h3>7.458[J] Advances in Biomanufacturing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m10a.html#10.03">10.03[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.548">7.548[J]</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.53">10.53[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br>Begins Apr 2. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-148</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar examines how biopharmaceuticals, an increasingly important class of pharmaceuticals, are manufactured. Topics range from fundamental bioprocesses to new technologies to the economics of biomanufacturing. Also covers the impact of globalization on regulation and quality approaches as well as supply chain integrity. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>C. Love</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.49"></a>
<p><h3>7.49[J] Developmental Neurobiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.18">9.18[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.69">7.69[J]</A>, <A HREF="m9a.html#9.181">9.181[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.01">9.01</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Considers molecular control of neural specification, formation of neuronal connections, construction of neural systems, and the contributions of experience to shaping brain structure and function. Topics include: neural induction and pattern formation, cell lineage and fate determination, neuronal migration, axon guidance, synapse formation and stabilization, activity-dependent development and critical periods, development of behavior. Students taking graduate version complete additional readings that will be addressed in their mid-term and final exams.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->

<h2>Graduate Subjects</h2>
<h3>MIT-WHOI Joint Program in Oceanography</h3>
<a name="7.410"></a>
<p><h3>7.410 Applied Statistics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Whoi dates TBA. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=54">54-823</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to modern applied statistics. Topics include likelihood-based methods for estimation, confidence intervals, and hypothesis-testing; bootstrapping; time series modeling; linear models; nonparametric regression; and model selection. Organized around examples drawn from the recent literature.
<br><I>WHOI Staff</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.411"></a>
<p><h3>7.411 Seminars in Biological Oceanography
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Selected topics in biological oceanography.
<br>Fall: <I>WHOI Staff</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Westwater</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.421"></a>
<p><h3>7.421 Problems in Biological Oceanography
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<a name="7.430"></a>
<p><h3>7.430 Topics in Quantitative Marine Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4

<br>Fall: <I>WHOI Staff</I><br>Spring: <I>WHOI Staff</I><br>No textbook information available

<a name="7.431"></a>
<p><h3>7.431 Topics in Marine Ecology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R4-5.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=WHOI CAMPUS">WHOI CAMPUS</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Lectures and discussions on ecological principles and processes in marine populations, communities, and ecosystems. Topics vary from year to year.
<br>Fall: <I>WHOI Staff</I><br>Spring: <I>WHOI Staff</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->

<a name="7.440"></a>
<p><h3>7.440 An Introduction to Mathematical Ecology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.30B">7.30B</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the basic models of population growth, demography, population interaction (competition, predation, mutualism), food webs, harvesting, and infectious disease, and the mathematical tools required for their analysis. Because these tools are also basic to the analysis of models in biochemistry, physiology, and behavior, subject also broadly relevant to students whose interests are not limited to ecological problems.
<br><I>M. Neubert</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.470"></a>
<p><h3>7.470 Biological Oceanography
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-191</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intended for students with advanced training in biology. Intensive overview of biological oceanography. Major paradigms discussed, and dependence of biological processes in the ocean on physical and chemical aspects of the environment examined. Surveys the diversity of marine habitats, major groups of taxa inhabiting those habitats, and the general biology of the various taxa: the production and consumption of organic material in the ocean, as well as factors controlling those processes. Species diversity, structure of marine food webs, and the flow of energy within different marine habitats are detailed and contrasted.
<br><I>WHOI Staff</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.491"></a>
<p><h3>7.491 Research in Biological Oceanography
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<h3>Microbiology (MICRO)</h3>
<a name="7.492"></a>
<p><h3>7.492[J] Methods and Problems in Microbiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.86">1.86[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.445">20.445[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students will read and discuss primary literature covering key areas of microbial research with emphasis on methods and approaches used to understand and manipulate microbes. Preference to first-year Microbiology and Biology students.
<br><I>M. Laub</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.493"></a>
<p><h3>7.493[J] Microbial Genetics and Evolution
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.87">1.87[J]</A>, <A HREF="m12b.html#12.493">12.493[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.446">20.446[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers aspects of microbial genetic and genomic analyses, central dogma, horizontal gene transfer, and evolution.
<br><I>A. D. Grossman, E. Alm</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
