<h2>Continuous Applied Mathematics</h2>
<a name="18.300"></a>
<p><h3>18.300 Principles of Continuum Applied Mathematics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-131</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers fundamental concepts in continuous applied mathematics. Applications from traffic flow, fluids, elasticity, granular flows, etc. Also covers continuum limit; conservation laws, quasi-equilibrium; kinematic waves; characteristics, simple waves, shocks; diffusion (linear and nonlinear); numerical solution of wave equations; finite differences, consistency, stability; discrete and fast Fourier transforms; spectral methods; transforms and series (Fourier, Laplace). Additional topics may include sonic booms, Mach cone, caustics, lattices, dispersion and group velocity. Uses MATLAB computing environment.
<br><I>L. Maltez Faria</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.300');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.303"></a>
<p><h3>18.303 Linear Partial Differential Equations: Analysis and Numerics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a> or <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.303">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.303</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-135</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides students with the basic analytical and computational tools of linear partial differential equations (PDEs) for practical applications in science and engineering, including heat/diffusion, wave, and Poisson equations. Analytics emphasize the viewpoint of linear algebra and the analogy with finite matrix problems. Studies operator adjoints and eigenproblems, series solutions, Green's functions, and separation of variables. Numerics focus on finite-difference and finite-element techniques to reduce PDEs to matrix problems, including stability and convergence analysis and implicit/explicit timestepping. Some programming required for homework and final project.
<br><I>C. Perez Arancibia</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.303');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.305"></a>
<p><h3>18.305 Advanced Analytic Methods in Science and Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.04">18.04</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.075">18.075</a>, or <a href="m18a.html#18.112">18.112</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers expansion around singular points: the WKB method on ordinary and partial differential equations; the method of stationary phase and the saddle point method; the two-scale method and the method of renormalized perturbation; singular perturbation and boundary-layer techniques; WKB method on partial differential equations.
<br><I>H. Cheng</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.306"></a>
<p><h3>18.306 Advanced Partial Differential Equations with Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.04">18.04</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.075">18.075</a>, or <a href="m18a.html#18.112">18.112</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.306">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.306</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-147</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Concepts and techniques for partial differential equations, especially nonlinear. Diffusion, dispersion and other phenomena. Initial and boundary value problems. Normal mode analysis, Green's functions, and transforms. Conservation laws, kinematic waves, hyperbolic equations, characteristics shocks, simple waves. Geometrical optics, caustics. Free-boundary problems. Dimensional analysis. Singular perturbation, boundary layers, homogenization. Variational methods. Solitons. Applications from fluid dynamics, materials science, optics, traffic flow, etc.
<br><I>R. Rosales</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.306');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.327"></a>
<p><h3>18.327 Topics in Applied Mathematics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/18.327">http://math.mit.edu/18.327</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-146</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics vary from year to year.
<br><I>L. Demanet</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.330"></a>
<p><h3>18.330 Introduction to Numerical Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Basic techniques for the efficient numerical solution of problems in science and engineering. Root finding, interpolation, approximation of functions, integration, differential equations, direct and iterative methods in linear algebra. Knowledge of programming in Fortran, C, or MATLAB helpful.
<br><I>M. Taus</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.335"></a>
<p><h3>18.335[J] Introduction to Numerical Methods
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.337">6.337[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.335">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.335</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-121</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced introduction to numerical analysis. Surveys major topics that arise at various levels of solving classic numerical problems, such as systems of linear equations, eigenvalue equations, and least squares problems. Specific topics include matrix factorizations (QR, SVD, LU, Cholesky); direct and iterative methods to solve linear systems (Gaussian elimination, Krylov subspace methods); numerical algorithms to solve eigenvalue equations (Rayleigh quotient iteration, inverse iteration, QR algorithm); conditioning of problems and stability of algorithms; and floating point arithmetic.
<br><I>W. Shin</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.336"></a>
<p><h3>18.336[J] Fast Methods for Partial Differential and Integral Equations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.335">6.335[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6b.html#6.336">6.336</a>, <a href="m16b.html#16.920">16.920</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.085">18.085</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.335">18.335</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Unified introduction to the theory and practice of modern, near linear-time, numerical methods for large-scale partial-differential and integral equations. Topics include preconditioned iterative methods; generalized Fast Fourier Transform and other butterfly-based methods; multiresolution approaches, such as multigrid algorithms and hierarchical low-rank matrix decompositions; and low and high frequency Fast Multipole Methods. Example applications include aircraft design, cardiovascular system modeling, electronic structure computation, and tomographic imaging.
<br><I>C. Perez Arancibia</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.337"></a>
<p><h3>18.337[J] Numerical Computing and Interactive Software
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.338">6.338[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Interdisciplinary introduction to computing with Julia. Covers scientific computing and data analysis problems.  Combines knowledge from computer science and computational science illustrating Julia's approach to scientific computing.  Sample scientific computing topics include dense and sparse linear algebra, Fourier transforms, data handling, machine learning, and N-body problems. Provides direct experience with the modern realities of programming supercomputers, GPUs, and multicores in a high-level language.
<br><I>A. Edelman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.338"></a>
<p><h3>18.338 Eigenvalues of Random Matrices
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://www.mit.edu/~18.338/">http://www.mit.edu/~18.338/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2-3.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-146</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the modern main results of random matrix theory as it is currently applied in engineering and science. Topics include matrix calculus for finite and infinite matrices (e.g., Wigner's  semi-circle and Marcenko-Pastur laws), free probability, random graphs, combinatorial methods, matrix statistics, stochastic operators, passage to the continuum limit, moment methods, and compressed sensing. Knowledge of MATLAB hepful, but not required.
<br><I>A. Edelman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.352"></a>
<p><h3>18.352[J] Nonlinear Dynamics: The Natural Environment
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m12a.html#12.009">12.009[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-162</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analyzes cooperative processes that shape the natural environment, now and in the geologic past. Emphasizes the development of theoretical models that relate the physical and biological worlds, the comparison of theory to observational data, and associated mathematical methods. Topics include carbon cycle dynamics; ecosystem structure, stability and complexity; mass extinctions; biosphere-geosphere coevolution; and climate change. Employs techniques such as stability analysis; scaling; null model construction; time series and network analysis.
<br><I>D. Rothman</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.353"></a>
<p><h3>18.353[J] Nonlinear Dynamics: Chaos
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as 2.050[J], <A HREF="m12a.html#12.006">12.006[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</a>; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to nonlinear dynamics and chaos in dissipative systems. Forced and parametric oscillators. Phase space. Periodic, quasiperiodic, and aperiodic flows. Sensitivity to initial conditions and strange attractors. Lorenz attractor. Period doubling, intermittency, and quasiperiodicity. Scaling and universality. Analysis of experimental data: Fourier transforms, Poincare sections, fractal dimension, and Lyapunov exponents. Applications to mechanical systems, fluid dynamics, physics, geophysics, and chemistry. See 12.207J/18.354J for Nonlinear Dynamics: Continuum Systems.
<br><I>H. Ronellenfitsch</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.354"></a>
<p><h3>18.354[J] Nonlinear Dynamics: Continuum Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1a.html#1.062">1.062[J]</A>, <A HREF="m12a.html#12.207">12.207[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18a.html#18.3541">18.3541</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</a>; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11.30-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-205</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>General mathematical principles of continuum systems. From microscopic to macroscopic descriptions in the form of linear or nonlinear (partial) differential equations. Exact solutions, dimensional analysis, calculus of variations and singular perturbation methods. Stability, waves and pattern formation in continuum systems. Subject matter illustrated using natural fluid and solid systems found, for example, in geophysics and biology.
<br><I>L. Bourouiba</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.3541"></a>
<p><h3>18.3541 Nonlinear Dynamics: Continuum Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m1a.html#1.062">1.062[J]</A>, <A HREF="m12a.html#12.207">12.207[J]</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.354">18.354[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</a>; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11.30-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-205</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>General mathematical principles of continuum systems. From microscopic to macroscopic descriptions in the form of linear or nonlinear (partial) differential equations. Exact solutions, dimensional analysis, calculus of variations and singular perturbation methods. Stability, waves and pattern formation in continuum systems. Subject matter illustrated using natural fluid and solid systems found, for example, in geophysics and biology. Students in Courses 1, 12, and 18 must register for undergraduate version, 18.354.
<br><I>L. Bourouiba</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.355"></a>
<p><h3>18.355 Fluid Mechanics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.354">18.354</a>, <a href="m2b.html#2.25">2.25</a>, or <a href="m12c.html#12.800">12.800</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics include the development of Navier-Stokes equations, inviscid flows, boundary layers, lubrication theory, Stokes flows, and surface tension. Fundamental concepts illustrated through problems drawn from a variety of areas, including geophysics, biology, and the dynamics of sport. Particular emphasis on the interplay between dimensional analysis, scaling arguments, and theory. Includes classroom and laboratory demonstrations.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.357"></a>
<p><h3>18.357 Interfacial Phenomena
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.354">18.354</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.355">18.355</a>, <a href="m12c.html#12.800">12.800</a>, <a href="m2b.html#2.25">2.25</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2-3.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-257</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fluid systems dominated by the influence of interfacial tension. Elucidates the roles of curvature pressure and Marangoni stress in a variety of hydrodynamic settings. Particular attention to drops and bubbles, soap films and minimal surfaces, wetting phenomena, water-repellency, surfactants, Marangoni flows, capillary origami and contact line dynamics. Theoretical developments are accompanied by classroom demonstrations. Highlights the role of surface tension in biology.
<br><I>J. Bush</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.358"></a>
<p><h3>18.358[J] Nonlinear Dynamics and Turbulence
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.686">1.686[J]</A>, <A HREF="m2a.html#2.033">2.033[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m1a.html#1.068">1.068</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m1a.html#1.060A">1.060A</a>
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Reviews theoretical notions of nonlinear dynamics, instabilities, and waves with applications in fluid dynamics. Discusses hydrodynamic instabilities leading to flow destabilization and transition to turbulence. Focuses on physical turbulence and mixing from homogeneous isotropic turbulence. Also covers topics such as rotating and stratified flows as they arise in the environment, wave-turbulence, and point source turbulent flows. Laboratory activities integrate theoretical concepts covered in lectures and problem sets. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.367"></a>
<p><h3>18.367 Waves and Imaging
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>The mathematics of inverse problems involving waves, with examples taken from reflection seismology, synthetic aperture radar, and computerized tomography. Suitable for graduate students from all departments who have affinities with applied mathematics. Topics include acoustic, elastic, electromagnetic wave equations; geometrical optics; scattering series and inversion; migration and backprojection; adjoint-state methods; Radon and curvilinear Radon transforms; microlocal analysis of imaging; optimization, regularization, and sparse regression.
<br><I>L. Demanet</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.369"></a>
<p><h3>18.369[J] Mathematical Methods in Nanophotonics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m8b.html#8.315">8.315[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.303">18.303</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.07">8.07</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-135</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>High-level approaches to understanding complex optical media, structured on the scale of the wavelength, that are not generally analytically soluable. The basis for understanding optical phenomena such as photonic crystals and band gaps, anomalous diffraction, mechanisms for optical confinement, optical fibers (new and old), nonlinearities, and integrated optical devices. Methods covered include linear algebra and eigensystems for Maxwell's equations, symmetry groups and representation theory, Bloch's theorem, numerical eigensolver methods, time and frequency-domain computation, perturbation theory, and coupled-mode theories.
<br><I>S. Johnson</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.369');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.376"></a>
<p><h3>18.376[J] Wave Propagation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1a.html#1.138">1.138[J]</A>, <A HREF="m2a.html#2.062">2.062[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.003">2.003</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.075">18.075</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.376/">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.376/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Theoretical concepts and analysis of wave problems in science and engineering with examples chosen from elasticity, acoustics, geophysics, hydrodynamics, blood flow, nondestructive evaluation, and other applications.  Progressive waves, group velocity and dispersion, energy density and transport. Reflection, refraction and transmission of plane waves by an interface. Mode conversion in elastic waves. Rayleigh waves. Waves due to a moving load. Scattering by a two-dimensional obstacle.  Reciprocity theorems. Parabolic approximation. Waves on the sea surface. Capillary-gravity waves. Wave resistance. Radiation of surface waves. Internal waves in stratified fluids.  Waves in rotating media.  Waves in random media.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.377"></a>
<p><h3>18.377[J] Nonlinear Dynamics and Waves
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.685">1.685[J]</A>, <A HREF="m2a.html#2.034">2.034[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/2.034/www/">http://web.mit.edu/2.034/www/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-147</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A unified treatment of nonlinear oscillations and wave phenomena with applications to mechanical, optical, geophysical, fluid, electrical and flow-structure interaction problems. Nonlinear free and forced vibrations; nonlinear resonances; self-excited oscillations; lock-in phenomena.  Nonlinear dispersive and nondispersive waves; resonant wave interactions; propagation of wave pulses and nonlinear Schrodinger equation.  Nonlinear long waves and breaking; theory of characteristics; the Korteweg-de Vries equation; solitons and solitary wave interactions.  Stability of shear flows.  Some topics and applications may vary from year to year.
<br><I>R. R. Rosales</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.377');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.384"></a>
<p><h3>18.384 Undergraduate Seminar in Physical Mathematics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.300">18.300</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.353">18.353</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.354">18.354</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the mathematical modeling of physical systems, with emphasis on the reading and presentation of papers. Addresses a broad range of topics, with particular focus on macroscopic physics and continuum systems: fluid dynamics, solid mechanics, and biophysics. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>S. Thomson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.385"></a>
<p><h3>18.385[J] Nonlinear Dynamics and Chaos
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2a.html#2.036">2.036[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the theory of nonlinear dynamical systems with applications from science and engineering. Local and global existence of solutions, dependence on initial data and parameters. Elementary bifurcations, normal forms. Phase plane, limit cycles, relaxation oscillations, Poincare-Bendixson theory. Floquet theory. Poincare maps. Averaging. Near-equilibrium dynamics. Synchronization.  Introduction to chaos. Universality. Strange attractors. Lorenz and Rossler systems. Hamiltonian dynamics and KAM theory. Uses MATLAB computing environment.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.397"></a>
<p><h3>18.397 Mathematical Methods in Physics
<br>(18.276)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.745">18.745</a> or some familiarity with Lie theory
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Content varies from year to year. Recent developments in quantum field theory require mathematical techniques not usually covered in standard graduate subjects.
<br><I>V. Kac</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Theoretical Computer Science</h2>
<a name="18.400"></a>
<p><h3>18.400[J] Automata, Computability, and Complexity
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.045">6.045[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.042">6.042</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.400">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.400</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-155</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Mathematical introduction to questions concerning the definition of computation, and what problems can be solved by computers. Considers what problems can be efficiently solved by way of finite automata, circuits, Turing machines, and communication complexity. Provides complete, rigorous answers to the questions in some cases; others are major open problems. Builds skills in classifying computational problems in terms of their difficulty. Discusses other fundamental issues, including the Church-Turing Thesis, the P versus NP problem, and the power of randomness.
<br><I>R. Rubinfeld</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.404"></a>
<p><h3>18.404 Theory of Computation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.840">6.840[J]</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.4041">18.4041[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.200">18.200</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.062">18.062J</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A more extensive and theoretical treatment of the material in 6.045J/18.400J, emphasizing computability and computational complexity theory. Regular and context-free languages. Decidable and undecidable problems, reducibility, recursive function theory. Time and space measures on computation, completeness, hierarchy theorems, inherently complex problems, oracles, probabilistic computation, and interactive proof systems.
<br><I>M. Sipser</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.4041"></a>
<p><h3>18.4041[J] Theory of Computation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.840">6.840[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18a.html#18.404">18.404</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.200">18.200</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.062">18.062J</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A more extensive and theoretical treatment of the material in 6.045J/18.400J, emphasizing computability and computational complexity theory. Regular and context-free languages. Decidable and undecidable problems, reducibility, recursive function theory. Time and space measures on computation, completeness, hierarchy theorems, inherently complex problems, oracles, probabilistic computation, and interactive proof systems. Students in Course 18 must register for the undergraduate version, 18.404.
<br><I>M. Sipser</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.405"></a>
<p><h3>18.405[J] Advanced Complexity Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.841">6.841[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.404">18.404</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Current research topics in computational complexity theory. Nondeterministic, alternating, probabilistic, and parallel computation models. Boolean circuits. Complexity classes and complete sets. The polynomial-time hierarchy. Interactive proof systems. Relativization. Definitions of randomness. Pseudo-randomness and derandomizations. Interactive proof systems and probabilistically checkable proofs.
<br><I>R. Williams</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.408"></a>
<p><h3>18.408 Topics in Theoretical Computer Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-237</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Study of areas of current interest in theoretical computer science. Topics vary from term to term.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Moitra</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Kelner</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.410"></a>
<p><h3>18.410[J] Design and Analysis of Algorithms
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.046">6.046[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.006">6.006</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><a href="https://learning-modules.mit.edu/class/index.html?uuid=/course/6/fa17/6.046J#info">https://learning-modules.mit.edu/class/index.html?uuid=/course/6/fa17/6.046J#info</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-101</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-168</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-168</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-168</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Techniques for the design and analysis of efficient algorithms, emphasizing methods useful in practice. Topics include sorting; search trees, heaps, and hashing; divide-and-conquer; dynamic programming; greedy algorithms; amortized analysis; graph algorithms; and shortest paths. Advanced topics may include network flow; computational geometry; number-theoretic algorithms; polynomial and matrix calculations; caching; and parallel computing.
<br>Fall: <I>V. Vassilevska Williams</I><br>Spring: <I>B. Tidor</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.410');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.415"></a>
<p><h3>18.415[J] Advanced Algorithms
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.854">6.854[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.042">6.042</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.600">18.600</a>; <a href="m6a.html#6.046">6.046</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>First-year graduate subject in algorithms. Emphasizes fundamental algorithms and advanced methods of algorithmic design, analysis, and implementation. Surveys a variety of computational models and the algorithms for them. Data structures, network flows, linear programming, computational geometry, approximation algorithms, online algorithms, parallel algorithms, external memory, streaming algorithms.
<br><I>D. Karger</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.416"></a>
<p><h3>18.416[J] Randomized Algorithms
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.856">6.856[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6c.html#6.854">6.854J</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.042">6.042J</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies how randomization can be used to make algorithms simpler and more efficient via random sampling, random selection of witnesses, symmetry breaking, and Markov chains. Models of randomized computation. Data structures: hash tables, and skip lists. Graph algorithms: minimum spanning trees, shortest paths, and minimum cuts. Geometric algorithms: convex hulls, linear programming in fixed or arbitrary dimension. Approximate counting; parallel algorithms; online algorithms; derandomization techniques; and tools for probabilistic analysis of algorithms.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.417"></a>
<p><h3>18.417 Introduction to Computational Molecular Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.01">6.01</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.006">6.006</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the basic computational methods used to model and predict the structure of biomolecules (proteins, DNA, RNA). Covers classical techniques in the field (molecular dynamics, Monte Carlo, dynamic programming) to more recent advances in analyzing and predicting RNA and protein structure, ranging from Hidden Markov Models and 3-D lattice models to attribute Grammars and tree Grammars.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.418"></a>
<p><h3>18.418 Topics in Computational Molecular Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.417">18.417</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.047">6.047</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://people.csail.mit.edu/bab/class/17-18.418-home.html">http://people.csail.mit.edu/bab/class/17-18.418-home.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11.30-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-132</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers current research topics in computational molecular biology.  Recent research papers presented from leading conferences such as the SIGACT International Conference on Computational Molecular Biology (RECOMB). Topics include original research (both theoretical and experimental) in comparative genomics, sequence and structure analysis, molecular evolution, proteomics, gene expression, transcriptional regulation, and biological networks. Recent research by course participants also covered. Participants will be expected to present either group or individual projects to the class.
<br><I>B. Berger</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.424"></a>
<p><h3>18.424 Seminar in Information Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.05">18.05</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.600">18.600</a>, or <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-132</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Considers various topics in information theory, including data compression, Shannon's Theorems, and error-correcting codes. Students present and discuss the subject matter.  Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>P. Shor</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.424');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.425"></a>
<p><h3>18.425[J] Cryptography and Cryptanalysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.875">6.875[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.046">6.046J</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-370</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A rigorous introduction to modern cryptography. Emphasis on the fundamental cryptographic primitives of public-key encryption, digital signatures, pseudo-random number generation, and basic protocols and their computational complexity requirements.
<br><I>S. Goldwasser</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.434"></a>
<p><h3>18.434 Seminar in Theoretical Computer Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.410">18.410</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics vary from year to year. Students present and discuss the subject matter. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>Y. Deshpande</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.435"></a>
<p><h3>18.435[J] Quantum Computation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2a.html#2.111">2.111[J]</A>, <A HREF="m8b.html#8.370">8.370[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to the theory and practice of quantum  computation. Topics covered: physics of information processing; quantum algorithms including the factoring algorithm and Grover's search algorithm; quantum error correction; quantum communication and cryptography. Knowledge of quantum mechanics helpful but not required.
<br><I>P. Shor</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.436"></a>
<p><h3>18.436[J] Quantum Information Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.443">6.443[J]</A>, <A HREF="m8b.html#8.371">8.371[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.435">18.435</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-190</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines quantum computation and quantum information. Topics include quantum circuits, the quantum Fourier transform and search algorithms, the quantum operations formalism, quantum error correction, Calderbank-Shor-Steane and stabilizer codes, fault tolerant quantum computation, quantum data compression, quantum entanglement, capacity of quantum channels, and quantum cryptography and the proof of its security. Prior knowledge of quantum mechanics required.
<br><I>A. Harrow</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.436');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.437"></a>
<p><h3>18.437[J] Distributed Algorithms
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.852">6.852[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.046">6.046</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Design and analysis of concurrent algorithms, emphasizing those suitable for use in distributed networks. Process synchronization, allocation of computational resources, distributed consensus, distributed graph algorithms, election of a leader in a network, distributed termination, deadlock detection, concurrency control, communication, and clock synchronization. Special consideration given to issues of efficiency and fault tolerance. Formal models and proof methods for distributed computation.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.453"></a>
<p><h3>18.453 Combinatorial Optimization
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18a.html#18.4531">18.4531</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Thorough treatment of linear programming and combinatorial optimization.  Topics include matching theory, network flow, matroid optimization, and how to deal with NP-hard optimization problems. Prior exposure to discrete mathematics (such as 18.200) helpful.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.4531"></a>
<p><h3>18.4531 Combinatorial Optimization
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18a.html#18.453">18.453</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Thorough treatment of linear programming and combinatorial optimization.  Topics include matching theory, network flow, matroid optimization, and how to deal with NP-hard optimization problems. Prior exposure to discrete mathematics (such as 18.200) helpful. Students in Course 18 must register for the undergraduate version, 18.453.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.455"></a>
<p><h3>18.455 Advanced Combinatorial Optimization
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.453">18.453</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced treatment of combinatorial optimization with an emphasis on combinatorial aspects. Non-bipartite matchings, submodular functions, matroid intersection/union, matroid matching, submodular flows, multicommodity flows, packing and connectivity problems, and other recent developments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
</td></tr></table>

<h2>Concourse HASS Subjects</h2>
<a name="CC.110"></a>
<p><h3>CC.110 Becoming Human: Ancient Greek Perspectives on the Good Life
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: CC.A10 or <a href="mCCa.html#CC.010">CC.010</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the question of the good life in the major literary and philosophic thinkers of ancient Greece.  Considers topics such as justice, moral virtue, friendship, love, and the life of the mind both for an individual and as part of society. Students debate the classical Greek answers to these questions and consider ways in which these answers apply to our present lives.  Includes selected works by authors such as Homer, Sophocles, Euripides, Aristophanes, Plato, Aristotle, and Epicurus. Limited to students in Concourse.
<br><I>L. Rabieh</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CC.111"></a>
<p><h3>CC.111[J] Modern Conceptions of Freedom
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m17a.html#17.04">17.04[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i>  <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students read early modern political theorists, and trace the growth of the value of freedom.  Examines the modern definition of freedom, and the obligations that people accept in honoring it.  Also investigates how these obligations are captured in the principles of our political association.  Studies how the centrality of freedom plays out in the political thought of such authors as Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Burke and Montesquieu.  Students also debate which notions of freedom inspire and sustain the American experiment by carefully reading the documents and arguments of the founding of the United States. Preference to students in Concourse.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CC.116"></a>
<p><h3>CC.116 How to Rule the World: The Promises and Pitfalls of Politics, War, and Empire
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the ambitions and constraints of political rule in order to understand how transformational leaders have (or should have) managed both in the service of good government. Employs normative and empirical methods to assess effective leadership, with particular attention to trade-offs between justice and security and to competing notions of justice itself. Includes case studies and various foundational texts that address the theme of great political leadership. Drawing on the texts, students discern different criteria for good rule and assess both the adequacy of those criteria and whether case studies support them. Preference to Concourse students.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CC.117"></a>
<p><h3>CC.117[J] Humane Warfare:  Ancient and Medieval Perspectives on Ethics in War
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m17a.html#17.05">17.05[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T3-5,R3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-160</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores questions of justice and ethics in war by focusing on primary texts of pre-modern works of history, philosophy, literature, and Biblical interpretation. Readings from antiquity include Thucydides, Aristophanes, and Cicero.  Examination of the Biblical tradition of just war, itself informed by the classical tradition, includes readings from early and Medieval Christian and Islamic thinkers and proceeds through the early Renaissance, with the beginning of a formalized doctrine of just war theory. Readings about current ethical dilemmas of war are discussed throughout and are given sustained attention at the end of the term. Preference to Concourse students.
<br><I>L. Rabieh</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CC.120"></a>
<p><h3>CC.120[J] Making Books in the Renaissance and Today
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Hb.html#21H.343">21H.343[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the impact of new technology on the recording and distribution of words and images at three different times: the invention of the printing press ca. 1450; the adaptation of electricity to communication technology in the 19th century (telegraph, telephone, phonograph); and the emergence of digital media today. Assignments include essays and online projects. Students participate in the design and construction of a hand-set printing press. Limited to 12.
<br><I>J. Ravel</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Concourse Seminars</h2>
<a name="CC.010"></a>
<p><h3>CC.010 Seminar I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with CC.A10)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>The key academic integration in which philosophical, historical, and sociological topics are connected with modern science. Combination of outside speakers and Concourse faculty lead weekly luncheon discussion. Limited to Concourse students.
<br><I>A. Mc Cants</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CC.011"></a>
<p><h3>CC.011 Seminar II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-1 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F12-2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-128</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Researchers from across MIT join the Concourse seminar to explore the topic of "Thinking Across the Disciplines." Concourse faculty lead weekly luncheon discussions with our guests from the wider MIT faculty. Preference to students in Concourse.
<br><I>A. Mc Cants</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CC.012"></a>
<p><h3>CC.012 Continuing Conversations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-1 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-136</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Close reading and vigorous discussion of an important book or theme, chosen to explore philosophical, ethical, and political questions that span the ages and disciplines.  Readings and themes vary by term.  Past examples include Aristotle's Physics, Plato's dialogue on knowledge, the Theaetetus, and a variety of writings that exemplify liberalism and conservatism in the American tradition. Preference to Concourse students.
<br>Fall: <I>L. Rabieh</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Rabieh</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Concourse Teaching and Research</h2>
<a name="CC.200"></a>
<p><h3>CC.200 Concourse Program Undergraduate Teaching
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Tutoring, leadership of study and review groups, seminars and recitations in the Concourse Program, under the supervision of senior Concourse staff. Limited to students in Concourse.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CC.210"></a>
<p><h3>CC.210 Independent Study
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Opportunity for independent study under regular supervision by a staff member. Projects require prior approval, as well as a written proposal and a final report. Limited to students in Concourse.
<br>Fall: <I>L. Rabieh</I><br>IAP: <I>L. Rabieh</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Rabieh</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CC.220"></a>
<p><h3>CC.220 Independent Study

<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">

<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CC.UR"></a>

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<br>Staff<br>Textbooks arranged individually
</p><!--end-->

<h1 align="center">Computational and Systems Biology<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://csbi.mit.edu/"><i>CSB Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=CSB&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+CSB&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>CSB.00- CSB.ZZZ</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>Computational Systems Biology</h2>
<a name="CSB.100"></a>
<p><h3>CSB.100[J] Topics in Computational and Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.89">7.89[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-10
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar based on research literature. Papers covered are selected to illustrate important problems and varied approaches in the field of computational and systems biology, and to provide students a framework from which to evaluate new developments. Preference to first-year CSB PhD students.
<br><I>C. Burge</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CSB.110"></a>
<p><h3>CSB.110 Research Rotations in Computational and Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-12-0 [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students carry out research rotations with MIT faculty members or principal investigators working in the field of computational and systems biology.  Generally three one-month long rotations are pursued that together span theoretical and experimental approaches. Open only to CSB PhD students.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CSB.190"></a>
<p><h3>CSB.190 Research Problems in Computational and Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Directed research in the field of computational and systems biology. Open only to CSB PhD students.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CSB.199"></a>
<p><h3>CSB.199 Teaching Experience in Computational Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For qualified graduate students in the CSB graduate program interested in teaching.    Classroom or laboratory teaching under the supervision of a faculty member.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CSB.THG"></a>
<p><h3>CSB.THG Graduate Thesis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Program of research leading to the writing of PhD thesis; to be arranged by the student and the MIT faculty advisor.
<br>Staff<br>Textbooks arranged individually
</p><!--end-->
</td></tr></table>
